data.title: The Manhattan Project (1986)
data.meta_description: Named after the World War II-era program, the plot revolves around a gifted high school student who decides to construct a nuclear bomb for a national science fair. The film's underlying theme involves the Cold War of the 1980s when government secrecy and mutually assured destruction were key political and military issues.
data.text:
First time I've seen this in more than 20 years. Just a few thoughts.

- I don't understand how Christopher Collet never really broke through. He had such a solid mid 80s. Sleepaway Camp, Firstborn, The Manhattan Project. Then his next movie is Prayer of the Rollerboys in 1990. On second thought, PotR may have been what did it.

- Lithgow is so good here. Par for the course for him but I love the subtle cues he has going. The strained conscience. The casual nature of his ultra high IQ. His mild social anxiety. The slow fraying of his nerves as the film progresses. He keeps all of these qualities sub-dermal. Great character work.

- Collet and Cynthia Nixon…

A lot of the negative reviews of The Manhattan Project on here focus on a couple of things (1) the unlikability of Paul, the main character, and (2) the dumbness of Paul's plan to build an atomic bomb to draw attention to the secret nuclear bomb development facility in his town.

I think, with respect, that those critiques kind of misread the film. I certainly understand that a blithely over-confident white man who seems unconcerned about the safety of those around him is a harder sell as a lead, watching this in 2021, than it may have been at the time, but I don't think you have to like the lead to enjoy the movie -- I think a large…

Good grief. This may have been a sweet movie in the mid 80's but this really does not hold up very well over the years.

A teen genius gets the great idea to steal plutonium from a government facility and build a nuclear bomb to show off as a science project to basically get back at a doctor who is dating his mother.

There are a lot of stars in this. John Lithgow, Jill Eikenberry, Cynthia Nixon, Robert Sean Leonard, John Mahoney, and Richard Jenkins cannot make this movie good.
